segments.text: Here's the list of stuff.
So what do you think about the topics I mentioned?
What was this item here?
Killer asteroids and comets.
Oh, yes, that's right.
Killer asteroids and comets.
Well, I'm just a bystander in all those subjects.
I'm just a professional who can...
But you're a taxpayer, and you know something about the subject.
Well, I'm a taxpayer in that sense, and I know something about the subject.
As a trained professional, a physics person, astronomy person, computing person, I'm certainly highly entitled to have an opinion, an informed opinion.
My own opinion is that the current budget level applied into the SETI, which...
what is it, 12 million a year or something, 15 million a year, is about right.
So I personally, were I sitting on a congressional committee, I would authorize the current efforts at roughly the current levels within factor of two.
I mean, I think maybe 20 million is an appropriate number instead of 10.
But, yeah, right in that ballpark.
I wouldn't put 100 million into it.
I wouldn't put a billion into it yet, not now.
In fact, my own private odds calculation is it's going to fail.
It's not going to find anything.
But it's a part of our ancient tradition, the search tradition, the research tradition.
It's a part of an ultimate human question.
And one of our goals as astronomers
is to face up to these ultimate questions that are outside the mundane existence that we... Those words that I'm using there sound almost religious, and I don't think that's an accident.

One of the reasons to gravitate to cosmology, for example, is the facing up to the ultimate cosmogonical questions, etiology and eschatology of all of existence, the where did we come from questions, the ultimate...
existential questions.
Well, SETI research is also in the category of ultimate existential questions.
And that is, I think, the real justification for doing it.
And whether or not it succeeds is sort of irrelevant.
The doing of it is what's really important.
So my reaction is about the current funding level is about right.
And it should be carried on probably forever.
It should be acknowledged to be one of those things that human beings ought to be doing just because it's an ultimate ideological question.
Now, killer asteroids are in a different category.
That's a straightforward, practical question.
No philosophy, no religiosity.
It's what's the odds they're going to hit us.
And it's also a kind of geological question because geologists would like to know how much has the Earth been pounded into smithereens.
and 65 million years ago kind of questions.
So I think that's perfectly reasonable to put money into, and probably the current funding levels are about right.
Other solar systems.
Well, that's...
If you're into planetary science, you'd sure like to know just what are the... How unusual is our planetary system?
Being...
or we say Copernicans philosophically.
We've been trained to think that we shouldn't really be in a unique preferred position.
But it's hard to tell when you only have one attitude.
That's right.
Well, once again, you see, my own attitudes are really much broader than the narrow professional interests that I officially did.
But I have to say that while I was a grad student,
I hadn't really developed my own philosophical attitudes about these matters.
I couldn't have expressed such opinions very well in those days.

But over the last 25 years or so, I gradually, since I moved to a lot of institutions, read a lot of journals, thought about it a lot, I developed a broader view of what is science, what is astronomy, and why are we doing it.
What do you think astronomy's position is today?
I mean, are we at a plateau?
Are we sinking or what?
These are the glory days of astronomy.
We are lucky to be in this generation.
We are living through the golden years of astronomy.
I would say these years correspond logically to being a physicist in the 20s, being a physicist in the 30s.
This is sort of like 1930 for physics.
Those were incredible years when all kinds of new instruments came online.
You just think about it.
In the 30s, there was Lawrence building cyclotrons.
Right here, yes.
Yeah, right here, yes.
And you had just finished up Rutherford, you know, and you were right in the midst of trying to understand quantum mechanics.
Well, right now, we are covering the entire frequency spectrum of photons that come to us from the universe here in this meeting of the AAS.
We have every kind of photon that gets to us from the universe is being discussed in the oral sessions or in the poster papers, and that's incredible.
When I was a grad student, when I entered graduate school in 1964, this was absolutely not true.
Radios...
And radio was puny.
It was pitiful.
Radio was meter wavelength, or just getting in the centimeter wavelength.
Not only that, but the interferometers could only tell you about fringe visibilities.
They couldn't tell you about a picture of the sky.
Now, 10 years ago, we had the VLA, and we could see the sky at one arc second resolution.
That was incredible.
When I was a grad student, you hadn't yet taken X-ray astronomy seriously.
So during my professional career, X-ray astronomy has gone from nothing to being a booming big deal.
Likewise, when I was a grad student, infrared detectors were junk.
You could hardly detect anything with them.
I mean, they were lucky to detect the brightest sources in the solar system, practically.
It was really hard work.
By the time I... Well, by now, of course, we have infrared cameras that are almost as good as the optical cameras.
You know, it can go on and on and on.
We've got gamma rays.
We've got a gamma ray observatory flying today.
We have gamma ray bursters, which were unknown.
Of course, when I entered grad school, pulsars hadn't been discovered.
And Martin Schmidt had only recognized 3C273 one year before.
So you just think about all the revolutionary things that have happened in the last 25 years, and you think about the last decade from NASA's point of view.
NASA's contribution of the great observatories, I think, is a heroic thing.
We're not alone in this.
The other cultures of the world, the Europeans, Japanese, the Russians, have all been a part of it.
So the whole frequency spectrum, from the highest frequencies to the lowest, is now wide open to astronomy.
There is essentially no phenomenon in the universe that can hide from us now.
There were things in the universe that were hidden from us 25 years ago.
Star formation.
Yeah, well, star formation, planetary systems.
Let's end this with one particular question.
What's your favorite Harlan Smith story?
Hard to choose.
Boy, do I have Harlan Smith stories?
I don't know.
For me, I don't know that I'm good at coming up with an answer to that kind of question.
I was amazed at his daring, his ability to promote and get money for his projects.
He had a profound influence on me.
I'm pretty sure that I got into his department because of his decision.
I think he was the one who, in some sense, chose me.
I think he hewed me as one of his proteges.
There was a meeting in Europe about five years ago, it was only a couple of years before he died, at which he was speaking.
I've forgotten what his topic was about.
I think it may have been computer controlled telescopes and instruments and information handling or something.
He was kind of brought in to give an overview of current of search as seen by an observatory director.
And he saw me in the crowd.
And he was saying extraordinarily complimentary things about me and really embarrassed me.
And yet, in fact, I was so embarrassed I almost couldn't take it afterwards.
I could hardly talk to him about it afterwards.
And yet, I also realized when I thought about it later on that this was almost quintessential Harlan, that he had picked people and he had backed them very thoroughly.
and that he really believed in them even in the face of what most people, objective observers, would have said contrary evidence, that Harlan was a promoter not just of projects but of people.
Is that a Harlan story?
It's not in your style, Ron.
It's a Harlan story.
It is a Harlan story.
I've gotten similar stories from other people.
Right.
And I'm sure that this led to inspiring a fierce loyalty in some people
In me, it inspired a great respect for him as a leadership person.

And that respect grew in my mind over the years as I had experience in other environments and organizations, and I understood the effect that one person could have, a leadership person, and that it was more than just promoting money or being a leadership person technically, that almost more important was the influence on people.
that I have grown in my opinion that people matter more than most other things.
That was something when I was a young student, I believed science was all logical and mathematical and people weren't the matter.
It was all technology and theory and all that.
And being much older and much wiser now, I have a rather different view of the world.
And I'm much more interested in people.
I've got to ask you this, although it probably won't appear in the book.
What was your first impression when you first saw Harlan, the observatory director?
Oh, my, the flat top.
He didn't look like your idea of an observatory director, did he?
No.
He didn't act like one either.
He wore, as I recall, he generally had a bolo tie like yours, your Texas bolo tie that you have there.
Yes, he went in for things like that.
So he was a kind of Texas promoter type, but he was really vigorous kind of person.
He was trusting forward, always trying to persuade people to go along with the ideas and to join the crowd and all that.
I would remark that I had one class from him.
I don't even remember what the title of the class was in which he lectured.
He lectured, and he was on stellar theory.
I remember one particular lecture he gave on how stars work.
And this wasn't really the official astrophysics class, stellar astrophysics class, which was taught by a different professor.
But it was a kind of one-hour overview of how stars work as machines, essentially.
And he tried to reduce everything to the simplest possible one line formula with a few constants.
And it was a big sort of power and units type, getting the exponents right and understanding why it's a square and not a cube and getting the units right.
And get your picture about what is it that matters in making stars work as engines.
And I thought it was very well done.
